column1: It may be caused by: - A defective Factor V gene passed down through families (inherited) - An antibody that interferes with normal Factor V function You can get an antibody that interferes with Factor V: - After giving birth - After being treated with a certain type of fibrin glue - After surgery - With autoimmune diseases and certain cancers Sometimes the cause is unknown.
The disease is similar to hemophilia, except bleeding into joints is less common.
